column1: Louny (Czech pronunciation: [ˈlounɪ]; German: Laun) is a town in the Ústí nad Labem Region of the Czech Republic. It has about 18
column2: 000 inhabitants. It is situated on the River Ohře.

column1: The town was founded in the 12th century (the first known written record dates from 1115). The Church of St Peter stands on the site of the original fort. The original name was Luna
column2: which is retained in the name of a local park
column4: and accounts for the Moon as part of the town's emblem. The town developed and expanded during the reign of Ottokar I of Bohemia
column5: although the Thirty Years' War depopulated the town. The second half of the 19th century witnessed the economic growth of the area.

column2: Laun – Louny was part of the Austrian monarchy (Austria side after the compromise of 1867)
column3: in the district of the same name
column4: one of the 94 Bezirkshauptmannschaften in Bohemia.

column1: The town lies on a railway junction and a factory for overhauling railway engines and rolling stock was established in 1873 which became a major employer and contributed to the town's expansion during the early 20th century. The former state company has now been privatized
column2: but remains the town's largest employer with a workforce of 750.

column1: Other industries include a brewery (from the hops which are grown in the region) and a factory making porcelain electrical insulators for power cables
The town's architecture was formed mainly in the 19th and 20th centuries when many old buildings were torn down. Nevertheless
column2: the most important architectural feature is Roman Catholic St. Nicholas Church
column3: erected between 1517 and 1537 in the late Gothic style. One of the architects was Benedikt Rejt. It incorporates a tower from an earlier church which was otherwise destroyed along with most of the town by a major fire in 1517.

column1: Parts of the town ramparts remain
column2: as does the Žatec Gate which dates from 1500 but was reconstructed in 1872.
